channel.title: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder
channel.description:
This is a very interesting news report, and I think this is pretty much the best example of what the 2nd amendment is for
http://gma.yahoo.com/video/news-26797925/oklahoma-mother-18-kills-intruder-breaking-into-her-home-while-on-phone-with-911-27777235.html
(its a video)
So, she was 18 and was trying to protect her 3 month old son. 2 men tried to break in, one armed with a hunting knife. She called 911 and asked "if they come through this door can I shoot them?" and they said "Im not going to tell you that, but do whatever you need to do to protect your baby" so the second they opened the door she killed him with a shotgun. Police ruled the murder as justified.
Obviously shed either be dead or kidnapped right now, along with her son had she not shot him. Should she have only shot him in the legs? Who gives a fuck. They had a knife, which means they had some intention of something. Now if this was soviet UK, they would have come in, she would have grabbed a frying pan, they would have stabbed her or robbed her or raped her, cops would get there too late, baby could be dead, but at least the maniac living 100 miles away didnt buy a gun and go shoot up a mall.
And even if you pull the argument "the knife was just a scare tactic, no one had to die." Uhh, thats retarded. If you even flash a gun or a knife to a cop they will shoot you (location depends on if it was a knife or a gun obviously). The intruders would have probably still been thrown in jail or back to doing drugs anyway so theyre better off dead.

item.title: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Davidi2:

Personally, while I think Budda’s example is a bit unrealistic, I do think there are better ways to deal with the situation. Like Niall suggested, leaving the house if possible is a fine example. She had 21 minutes, correct? Why keep yourself and your family in a dangerous environment?

She had 21 minutes (before they kicked in the door) of them going around to all the windows and doors of the house trying to break in, how are you going to sneak away from them with a baby in that situation? You couldn’t.

sspoke:

i’m sure they didn’t try to rape her… they just wanted to rob her house… she should of given them the chance too see how it would play out instead of taking immediate action.

How the hell do you have any idea what they were trying to do? She didn’t know either. You are saying she should have let them get within arms reach of her and her baby before trying to stop them? That’s ridiculous. She didn’t take ‘immediate action’, that would have been shooting through the door to kill the bastards. She was terrified waiting for police for over 21 minutes while they tried to get in, and when they finally KICKED IN THE DOOR she shot them.

I said this before, I’ll say it again, someone doesn’t kick in your fucking door to sit down and have some tea and crumpets with you. They want to hurt you obviously.

Read full topic
item.source: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder

item.title: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:48, topic:428078”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=530764.msg3880069#msg3880069 date=1325974339]
Umm the same goes for the US? You cant just invite someone into your house and kill them and its fucking justified, your life has to be in danger
[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

Castle doctrine

A castle doctrine, also known as a castle law or a defense of habitation law, is a legal doctrine that designates a person's abode or any legally occupied place (for example, a vehicle or home) as a place in which that person has protections and immunities permitting one, in certain circumstances, to use force (up to and including deadly force) to defend oneself against an intruder, free from legal prosecution for the consequences of the force used. The term is most commonly used in the United A ...

Specifically, the stand your ground stuff[/quote]
Does anybody calls that self-defence? I wonder if I can use the law to use deadly force against Jehovah’s Witnesses and other preachers, they are threaten me with hell…

Read full topic

Mopman:

“i had no time to save myself, only enough time to have a chat with the 911 operator”

Holding phone on her shoulder with a shotgun vs picking up her son and crawling out the back window or back door which any idiot would hear in a small ass trailer hoping the baby wouldn’t start crying.

item.title: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:49, topic:428078”]Now that I think about it, the 911 call was an amazing idea. Even if what she did was questionable, she would have the phone log of her probably talking like a panicked crazy person.
I’ll keep that in mind if someone ever breaks into my house; it seems like a great way to strengthen your defense.[/quote]

I’d shoot, then make the call. Immediately of course. Just because pausing to call the police while someone tries to kill me doesn’t seem like an effective use of time.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Mopman:

like i said, you have to respond reasonably, if you believe your life is in danger, using deadly force is fine, but not otherwise. we dont have anything like the “king of the castle” type thing the USA has where simply being in your house is an excuse to kill them

castle laws, you can be shot for trespassing if they have a sign up, but yes if theyre just in your house they can shoot you and I dont see a problem with that.

item.description:
@Thebeanie wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:6, topic:428078”]You know, if this happened in the UK, it would be exactly the same right?

“A man about to be attacked does not have to wait for his assailant to strike the first blow or fire the first shot; circumstances may justify a pre-emptive strike.”[/quote]

Actually, The house holder can still be done for murder / manslaughter, Depends on the situation and whether its deemed as threat to life, Like… if they came into your bedroom where you were sleeping i read your allowed to do somethin… But if you heard them downstairs for example… your supposed to try and get out the house and ring the police.

Honestly, it’s not the color that matters, it’s the lifestyle when I look at potential threats. I live in a very ethnic place (we don’t have any white immediate neighbors), and I know they are respectable people by only talking to them once or twice.

In the city, I get uneasy around whites AND blacks, you can usually even tell by just the way they talk, dress etc

cumescape:

@Speljohan: I personally wouldn’t want to be in a neighborhood full of black people, because I know I would end up getting robbed.

I don’t know about being robbed, but unfortunately in America being surrounded by black Americans gives you a uneasy feeling because racism is still very much alive and its a problem that will never cease to exist in America. The hatred for each other goes really deep on both sides, we just see now that the black tend to be much more racists than the whites. That’s not to say the white’s are not as equally racists (HELLO REPUBLICAN PARTY CURRENTLY IN OFFICE)

item.title: 18 year old calls 911 before shooting intruder
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:32, topic:428078”][quote author=tL link=topic=530764.msg3877293#msg3877293 date=1325766054]
But when the views opposite of what are expressed in this topic are enforced in law, why are crime rates so high?
[/quote]
Because most people don’t take advantage of the 2nd amendment, and when you don’t you give te criminals an upper hand. If 8 in 10 citizens had a gun crime rates would be so low.[/quote]

4.8 out of every 100k US citizens were intentionally murdered in 2010. 0.87 in the Netherlands. We aren’t allowed to own guns. US citizens are. So owning a gun won’t make a difference.

The income inequality in the US is much higher than any European country. Perhaps the fact that being poor in the US means you have to resort to crime is a great, if not the main cause of the high crime rates in the US.

Read full topic
